text: It is so interesting to see him consider his life work to be entirely futile. The modern thought to legalize narcotics interesting, but his contention that use will go down sounds like a guess. Use didn't go down when alcohol prohibition was relaxed. If legalization comes with restriction, then there will always be a black market for those who don't want to jump through the hoops of social control. Of course those people wouldn't be counted in overall statistics. The strongest argument in favor of legalization would be the collapse of the fentanyl market, and the anticipated decline in crime. The increase in employment for those who dispense and monitor drug use should be offset by dramatically lower policing cost. However expecting most addicts to regain employment sounds like a pipe dream.Ôªø

Decriminalize, regulate, and focus on harm reduction rather than criminalization.  
People who's drug use controls their lives should be put into treatment rather than jail -

Portugal already has this model, and it reduced their nationwide addiction rates significantly
And without an illegal market anymore,
The drug cartels would crumble.  

It would reduce crime, reduce drug use, save lives, give back bodily autonomy to the people, and cost less taxes.  There are no down sides.Ôªø

author: Phong Nguyen

text:
your comment is puzzling to me but I am going to try and have a discussion.  The drug prohibition was largely related to racism and many other things, sure,  However, one really big issue with opiods is this.  During the 1990s, there was a new generation of opiod analgesic painkillers which were marketed by the chemists/research as being nearly zero addiction, around 1%.  This however was found out to be extremely wrong.  However, doctors who were trained during this time period, were taught that these new painkillers were relatively safe when it came to dependencies.  So that is one reason why there has been a massive over prescription for opiod painkillers.  When you are addicted to opiods, and your doctor cuts off your prescription because you dont need it for the injury anymore, you either suffer serious withdrawals (many people simply cant handle it) so they decide to go out and buy heroin.  When you consume drugs off the street heroin especially, there is a high chance the drug is going to be impure, or cut with different unknown drugs, such as fentanyl.  The reason for this is, you can make a product much more strong and sell more, allowing the drug dealer to get more profit.  However, the user takes their regular dose and overdoses.  The overdose is because the drug wasnt regulated, and this is because the drug is illegal. More people die every single year from alcohol Overdose alone, than any other drug combined,  This is not including the bigger amount of the people who got drunk, did something stupid or wrecked in traffic and died.  This is strictly alcohol overdoses.  Harm reduction is a different approach to drug use, rather then arresting people, locking them up, getting them stuck inside the in and out of prison, (felons cant get a decent job, if you get a felony drug possession, your fucked.) We can inform them how to use drugs safely, how to know about addiction and how to get help.  Rather then DARE style of DONT DO ANY DRUGS, we have to accept that a certain percentage of people are going to use drugs and we have to minimize the harm that comes with that.  if you werent aware, weed, lsd, shrooms and heroin (assuming its pure and not overdose) are all quite literally safer for your body than tobacco or alcohol.  So, drug laws arent there to really protect people, something else has happened and its causing a whole ton of issues.

     Disregarding hypotheticals, if you want to know what actually happens when a nation decriminalizes drugs, look at Portugal.  They have seen a massive reduction in drug addiction rates and drug related deaths.  When drugs are illegal, violent gangs come into play, product is sketchy and things are not safe, and information is scarce because its illegal.Ôªø

author: Phong Nguyen

text:
I feel as if there is some misunderstanding, drug laws are not in place because of racism today, this was during times 100 years ago.  News reports from the early 1900s clearly show strange stories, such is a case of yellow journalism. The Harrison Narcotics Tax Act was a federal law put into place as a response to these events.  
"The drafters played on fears of "drug-crazed, sex-mad negroes" and made references to Negroes under the influence of drugs murdering whites, degenerate Mexicans smoking marijuana, and "Chinamen" seducing white women with drugs.[20][21] Dr. Hamilton Wright, testified at a hearing for the Harrison Act. Wright alleged that drugs made blacks uncontrollable, gave them superhuman powers and caused them to rebel against white authority. Dr. Christopher Koch of the State Pharmacy Board of Pennsylvania testified that "Most of the attacks upon the white women of the South are the direct result of a cocaine-crazed Negro brain". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harrison_Narcotics_Tax_Act
Please, I'm not trying to push some conspiracy.  The things I am discussing are truly fact, I'm not saying that is the only reason however it is a big reason.  And this isnt just about racism, it was also used as an attack against the counter culture movement, anti war protesters. and against racial revolutionary groups like the Black Panthers. 
Here is a direct statement which was made by John Ehrlichman (counsel and Assistant to the President for Domestic Affairs under President Richard Nixon)  Quoted in the year 1994: "The Nixon campaign in 1968, and the Nixon White House after that, had two enemies: the antiwar left and black people. You understand what I'm saying? We knew we couldn't make it illegal to be either against the war or black, but by getting the public to associate the hippies with marijuana and blacks with heroin, and then criminalizing both heavily, we could disrupt those communities. We could arrest their leaders, raid their homes, break up their meetings, and vilify them night after night on the evening news. Did we know we were lying about the drugs? Of course we did."

I agree with you in part regarding the issue of racism this, racism that.  For some people, they think every problem in the US is rooted in racism.  However, I'm asking you to set the association of those other opinions aside, as this is is a separate and very real issue.  The reason I'm so passionate about putting this information out to you and others on youtube, this is a central issue in my career field.  I've done considerably more research than average, and I believe for the problem to hopefully improve, people need to understand true factors at play.Ôªø

text: I'd say the racist drug policies really derive from the U.S. during the Reagan era. Crack cocaine was being produced in South America and imported into the states, all under the direction of the CIA disguised as the cartels. I don't mean it as if the CIA agents we're literally cartel members, but that they intentionally allowed this to go on because it allowed for the government to target the black community. This may sound like a conspiracy theory to someone that's not knowledgeable, but it's not- an advisor to the president and high ranking person in the CIA famously said that they used the artificial crack cocaine and marijuana epidemic to target and disrupt the black and hippy communities. In fact, punishment for crack cocaine (a crystalized form of cocaine that was cheaper to produce by using less actual cocaine) had a far greater punishment than normal cocaine. The reason this is important is because normal cocaine could be found in middle-class suburban areas whereas crack was found in poorer areas, because it was more affordable. Both are cocaine, however the cheaper and dirtier form gave a harsher sentence. Political rhetoric by the Reagan and again by the Nixon administration furthered the idea of a drug epidemic in this country to give them a leg up in the political races, because while other politicians we're talking about standard issues, these politicians had talking points no one else had, and they were determined to fix this problem everyone was now aware of. It was political and racist, and the administration's pushed this anti-drug agenda to maintain the idea of a drug ravaged country by incentivizing police departments to make more drug related arrests and other forms to maintain the narrative. This all also fed the growing private prison industry- but that's a whole 'nother bag of worms.Ôªø

author: jonnybaze

text:
Absolutely agreed.  It seems counter-intuitive, but it reduces drug abuse, drug deaths, and tax payer expense.  
It would also remove the primary revenue stream from drug cartels who are terrorizing South America.  We could even use it to generate tax revenue, like the marijuana industry has done in many states, providing millions of dollars.  
Perhaps rather than total legalization, decriminalization might be a better step, but that discussion can't even be had from the position we currently sit - locking people in jail, costing tax payers millions, while letting them die injecting unregulated fentanyl laced drugs, and giving the cartels all the money they need to dominate a continent.Ôªø
author: Danielle Spargo

text:
Adam Cantrell
Portugal has already implemented something similar, and it significantly reduced drug use.  Treatment is not only cheaper to the tax payer than prison, but it's also far more effective at reducing usage.  We've already seen in America that the clean needle programs significantly reduced the spread of hepatitis and HIV, though unfortunately the programs haven't been adopted throughout the country.  

I understand that it's counter-intuitive, but it really does work.  It really does reduce drug usage.  We have already seen how effective it is when implemented in the actual real world.  I understand why you are hesitent, but your fears are unfounded, and based on a false premise.  Our streets are already flooded with drugs, and they're dirty and impure, killing users who think they're buying something else.  We need to change the system, because that horrible "black" situation you described already exists within the current paradigm, so clearly it's not effective.Ôªø

text:
@liquidminds I've worked in drug rehab and aftercare services for close to a couple of decades now. I've been involved in a number of initiatives involving local police forces. Unfortunately there is a large amount of police at ALL levels who don't care about the destruction they cause, or ultimately who they arrest. As long as their ultimate arrest records appear high it's "job well done".

Not to say they're all like that. Far from it. Ironically the ones really wanting to make a change, frequently end up leaving the police and working somewhere in the treatment, rehab and/or aftercare sector.Ôªø
author: Rin Tin

text: @liquidminds The methods of the police can be so cruel and destructive that you must question their intentions as well.
